Graphical abstract Biomass-derived carbon materials have attractive merits, such as low carbon emission in the life cycle and diversity in the structure and performance due to the wide source of biomass feedstocks. In this work, the research progress on the electrochemical reduction of O2 to produce H2O2 over biomass-derived carbon-based catalysts has been comprehensively reviewed. H2O2 is one of the most important chemicals in the world. Recently, the electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 by two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e− ORR) has attracted great interest. Carbon-based catalysts show great promise for electrocatalytic production of H2O2, due to the ease of regulation of the carbon materials with regard to the pore structure, surface properties, and heteroatom doping. Biomass as the carbon precursor has the advantages of low cost, sustainable supply, and extensive availability. Conversion of biomass to functional carbon-based materials shows the attractive merits, such as low carbon emission in the life cycle and diversity of the obtained carbon materials due to the wide source of biomass feedstocks. In this article, a comprehensive review on the mechanisms and processes of electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 by 2e− ORR over carbon-based catalysts is provided. The potential biomass feedstock used for obtaining the carbon-based catalysts, and the strategies to prepare the catalysts by carbonization and heteroatom doping, as well as optimization of electrodes and design of electrolyzer, are discussed. It is recommended that future work focus on developing efficient methods to prepare the catalysts from low-cost biomass feedstock, understanding the mechanisms of 2e− ORR over the catalysts, optimization of electrode materials loaded with biomass-derived catalysts, as well as development of electrolyzers for larger-scale applications. Keywords Hydrogen peroxide Electrochemical reduction Carbon-based catalyst Biomass-derived carbon materials Reduction of oxygen 1 Introduction 1.1 Widespread use of hydrogen peroxide As one of the 100 most important chemicals in the world, hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) is a strong, environmentally friendly, atom-economical oxidizer widely used in bleaching, chemical synthesis, disinfection, and wastewater treatment [1]. Practically, dilute H2O2 solutions are effective for direct use in potable water treatment and routine household sanitation [2]. Besides, H2O2 as a sustainable energy carrier in the fuel cell has advantages in easy storage and high energy density [3–5]. The global H2O2 market is projected to grow at a 4.6 % compound annual growth rate (CAGR), reaching 5.7 million tons by 2028 [6]. Currently, more than 95 % of H2O2 production relies on the energy-intensive anthraquinone oxidation process, with safety risks and extra costs during transportation and storage [7,8]. As a promising alternative, the electrosynthesis of H2O2 through two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e− ORR) allows green, decentralized, and on-site H2O2 generation [9]. Recent studies have focused extensively on designing catalysts for electrochemical 2e− ORR, with carbon-based materials emerging as predominant precursors for catalyst synthesis. Some progress on metal-free or single-atom catalysts has been presented in several review articles [10,11]. However, systematic reviews on carbonaceous catalysts for 2e− ORR, especially on the biomass-derived carbon-based catalysts in terms of mechanism, catalyst design, electrode, and electrolyzer fabrication, are relatively scarce. In this review, we have summarized recent advances in electrochemical H2O2 production via 2e− ORR, with particular emphasis on biomass-derived carbon materials from synthesis strategies to catalytic applications. We also have discussed electrode materials and electrolyzer design, offering valuable guidance for future research of biomass-based carbons in 2e− ORR systems. 1.2 Current technologies for the production of H2O2 1.2.1 Anthraquinone oxidation process The anthraquinone oxidation (AO) process includes anthraquinone hydrogenation, anthrahydroquinone oxidation, H2O2 extraction, and the post-treatment of the working solution (Fig. 1 a). 2-Alkylanthraquinone in an organic solvent is hydrogenated catalytically to hydroquinone first. After separating from the catalyst (Pd/Ni), hydroquinone is oxidized with air to regenerate the anthraquinone while simultaneously producing H2O2. The H2O2 is then extracted from the organic phase using water in a countercurrent column, yielding a 30 wt% H2O2 aqueous solution, which can be further concentrated to 70 wt% via distillation. Meanwhile, the recovered organic solvent containing anthraquinone is purified and recycled back into the process [7]. The AO process is usually performed as a batch operation on a large scale, but without direct contact with H2 and O2. It has the advantages, including high process maturity, relatively high security, low cost, and ease of equipment scale-up. However, some apparent drawbacks also exist for the AO process. Firstly, the H2 required is usually from high-temperature methane reforming, which is capital-intensive with high energy consumption [14], and the energy derived from fossil fuel combustion substantially increases the carbon footprint [7]. Secondly, the AO process is usually conducted on a large scale and certain area. However, in applications like distributed disinfection, sanitation, and water treatment, on-site H2O2 generation is increasingly preferred [14–16], making the AO process less suitable. Besides, highly concentrated H2O2 is explosive, increasing the safety risk during transportation and storage, and the concentration-dilution process sometimes is energy intensive. Third, the AO process has problems of emitting exhaust gas, wastewater, and solid waste. In addition, commercial H2O2 solution contains mechanical, inorganic, and organic impurities [17]. The addition of a stabilizer to alleviate H2O2 decomposition makes the composition more complex. These motivate researchers to develop a small-scale and decentralized H2O2 production method that integrates energy conversion and chemical synthesis near the point of use, ensuring sustainability and continuous operation [1,8,14–17]. 1.2.2 Direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 The direct synthesis of H2O2 from H2 and O2 is a typical atom-economical reaction. The catalytic mechanism involves the stepwise hydrogenation of oxygen (Fig. 1b): H2 molecules undergo dissociative adsorption on the catalyst surface, forming hydrogen atoms; then O2 molecules adsorb onto the catalyst and react with the hydrogen atoms, generating *OOH intermediates, which are subsequently hydrogenated to form H2O2. This process is a complex three-phase reaction (H2/O2 mixed gas phase as reactants, solid-based metal catalysts, and solvent as the reaction medium) [18]. This process has two major problems of low yield and inherent flammability hazard. H2O2 is inherently highly reactive, and the existence of H2 promotes the hydrogenation and decomposition into water. While adding strong acids and halides to the solvent can inhibit these undesired reactions on Pd-based catalysts, such additives may accelerate metal leaching. Consequently, additional purification of the produced H2O2 is often necessary before use [16]. In addition, to mitigate the flammability risk posed by mixing high-pressure H2 and O2, the feedstock should be significantly diluted by inert gas, such as CO2 and N2. This requirement complicates the operational process and leads to a notable reduction in H2O2 yield [8,19]. Electrosynthetic methods that decouple the H2/O2 redox into two half-reactions have been explored for H2O2 production. However, these approaches are still limited by slow reaction kinetics, low current efficiency, and the requirement for additional separation steps [19]. Hence, the scale-up of this process to industrial application is currently unfeasible. 1.2.3 Photocatalytic synthesis of H2O2 via 2e− ORR Photocatalytic and electrocatalytic methods for H2O2 production typically rely on two main pathways: the cathodic oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and the anodic water oxidation reaction (WOR). Compared to the traditional anthraquinone process, both approaches offer improved chemical stability, easier storage and transport, and the ability to operate under mild conditions. At present, research efforts are largely concentrated on the 2e− ORR pathway, which offers high current efficiency, whereas the WOR pathway has received less attention due to its comparatively lower efficiency [20]. Photocatalysis generally involves three key steps: light absorption, charge carrier separation, and surface redox reaction (Fig. 1c). When the energy of incident light (E hv) exceeds the semiconductor’s bandgap (E g), the semiconductor is activated with electrons transferring from the valence band (VB) to the conduction band (CB) to form electron-hole pairs (e−/h+). The photo-induced electrons with reducing capacity and holes with oxidizing capacity then migrate to the surface of the photocatalyst. The charge carriers can propel the redox reactions with chemical species when provided with the necessary overpotentials [13,21]. Traditional photocatalysts synthesize H2O2 through the indirect two-step one-electron reduction pathway, rather than the one-step two-electron reduction, which can avoid the existence of O2− [22]. The photocatalysis using renewable solar energy to convert O2 into H2O2 offers a sustainable and on-demand technique for H2O2 production. Nevertheless, photocatalytic production of H2O2 is still in the early stage, facing several challenges with respect to the suitable range of photon absorption, the effective separation of charge carriers, and the selectivity and rate of surface reactions [13]. Therefore, current research in this field primarily aims to enhance catalyst efficiency and selectivity, minimize the recombination of photo-generated charge carriers, and suppress the light-induced (λ < 400 nm) decomposition of the produced H2O2 [23–25]. 1.2.4 Electrosynthesis of H2O2 via 2e− ORR Electrosynthesis of H2O2 through the 2e− ORR pathway powered by renewable electricity presents a promising approach for green, decentralized, and on-demand H2O2 production [26]. This method was initially demonstrated by Berl in 1939, who employed activated carbon cathodes and achieved a current efficiency exceeding 90 % [27]. Dow and H-D Tech implemented this approach in the Huron-Dow process for on-site generation of alkaline H2O2 at concentrations of 3–4 wt%, primarily for use in the paper and pulp industry. Their developed trickle-bed electrolyzer maintained a current efficiency above 80 % even after six months without cathode replacement [15]. Despite the successful commercialization of the Huron-Dow process in 1991, the strong alkalinity of the electrolyte introduces several challenges, such as electrode corrosion, carbonate buildup due to CO2 absorption, and increased Ohmic resistance, all of which hinder its continued advancement [12]. Electrocatalysts for H2O2 production are generally classified into two major types based on the electrolyte used (Fig. 1d) [12]. In strongly alkaline environments, such as in the Huron-Dow process, carbon-based or modified carbon catalysts [28–30] are typically employed to produce hydroperoxide anions (HO2 −). In contrast, metal-based catalysts are suitable for acidic and neutral conditions to directly produce H2O2 [1,31], which have also been integrated into solid electrolyte electrolysis devices to enable H2O2 generation in pure water [14,19]. Although metal-based catalysts exhibit high activity, they are limited by issues such as high cost, low selectivity, limited stability, and potential environmental risks [32]. Carbon-based materials, particularly those derived from biomass, show strong potential for efficient 2e− ORR catalysis due to their abundance, low cost, excellent electrical conductivity, and structural stability [33]. However, despite advances in identifying active catalysts, many highly effective doped nanocarbons have been discovered through trial and error. A deep understanding of how dopant-induced active sites form and how different doping strategies influence catalytic properties remains limited. Furthermore, H2O2 is prone to significant self-decomposition under elevated temperatures (above 23 °C) and strongly alkaline conditions (pH > 9), posing an additional challenge [7,34]. Devices utilizing hydroxide-conducting polymer electrolytes are still facing limitations such as limited hydrogen oxidation activity, inadequate membrane durability, and suboptimal water management [1]. To ensure the stability of H2O2, it is essential to optimize factors like mass transport and electrolyte pH through thoughtful reactor and process design. Accordingly, this review also highlights recent developments and challenges in cathode electrode structures and practical electrolyzer configurations for H2O2 electrosynthesis using carbon-based catalysts. 2 Fundamentals of electrocatalytic 2e− ORR 2.1 Mechanisms of the electrocatalytic ORR Electrocatalytic oxygen reduction can proceed via two distinct pathways: a two-electron route that generates H2O2 and a four-electron route that leads to the formation of H2O. Specifically, the reaction mechanisms are dependent on the pH values of the electrolyte [35,36]. The standard reduction potential of O2 to HO2 − is −0.076 V versus standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) for the direct two-electron pathway. (1) O 2 + H 2 O+2 e - ⇌ H O 2 - +O H - ( E 0 = - 0.076 V vs. SHE ) followed by either further reduction or disproportionation (2) H O 2 - + H 2 O+2 e - ⇌ 3 O H - ( E 0 = 0. 878 V vs. SHE ) (3) 2 H O 2 - ⇌ 2 O H - + O 2 O2 can also be reduced to OH− in a four-electron pathway directly. (4) O 2 + 2 H 2 O + 4 e - ⇌ 4 O H - ( E 0 = 0.401 V vs. SHE ) In acidic media, the reactions taking place in two-electron (O2 to H2O2) and four-electron pathways (O2 to H2O) include (5) O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - ⇌ H 2 O 2 ( E 0 = 0.695 V vs. SHE ) (6) H 2 O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - ⇌ 2 H 2 O ( E 0 = 1.776 V vs. SHE ) (7) 2 H 2 O 2 ⇌ O 2 +2 H 2 O (8) O 2 + 4 H + + 4 e - ⇌ 2 H 2 O ( E 0 = 1.229 V vs. SHE ) In non-standard conditions, the equilibrium potential of oxygen electrode reactions could be calculated according to the Nernst equation. (9) E = E 0 - RT nF ln a Ox a Red If in the alkaline media at 25 °C and an O2 pressure of 1 atm, the Nernst equation could be simplified as follows to get the equilibrium potential of O2/HO2 − versus reversible hydrogen electrode (vs. RHE). (10) E R H E = E S H E + 0.0592 × p H Fig. 2 illustrates the mechanisms of the two-electron and four-electron ORR. In the diagram, * indicates a vacant catalytic site, while *OOH, *O, and *OH denote different oxygen-containing intermediates. The two-electron route involves two sequential steps of proton and electron transfer. Initially, an O2 molecule is adsorbed onto an active catalytic site, where it combines with a proton (H+) and an electron (e−) to generate the intermediate *OOH. This intermediate then undergoes a second proton-electron coupling to yield H2O2, completing the two-electron pathway [1,35–38]. However, the adsorbed O2 may follow the four-electron ORR pathway, in which the O–O bond of *OOH intermediate may cleave in distinct ways to form *O and *OH species, ultimately yielding H2O. Furthermore, the generated H2O2 is prone to undergoing subsequent electroreduction or disproportionation, also resulting in H2O formation. The reaction pathway and product selectivity are closely influenced by the stability of the O–O bond, which depends on the binding energy of the *OOH intermediate on the catalyst surface. According to Sabatier’s principle, an effective catalyst should strongly adsorb O2 to facilitate *OOH formation, yet bind *OOH weakly enough to enable its easy desorption as H2O2. This balance ensures both high reduction activity and favorable selectivity toward H2O2 production [1,38]. 2.2 Evaluation parameters of 2e− ORR electrocatalysts The rotating ring disk electrode (RRDE) is a key electrochemical technique commonly used to evaluate the activity and selectivity of ORR catalysts (Fig. 3 a) [12,35]. The RRDE system operates under convective conditions and comprises a rotating shaft, a glassy carbon disk electrode that records oxygen reduction currents, and a concentric platinum ring electrode that detects the oxidation currents of H2O2 [35]. The ORR occurs at the disk electrode, producing H2O2 and H2O. The generated H2O2 is then transported radially to the ring electrode through rotation-induced convective mass transfer, where it is oxidized back to O2. (11) H 2 O 2 → O 2 + 2 H + + 2 e - Fig. 3(b) presents a representative ORR polarization curve obtained with a rotating disk electrode (RDE), which, unlike RRDE, includes only a disk electrode mounted on a rotating shaft and lacks the surrounding ring electrode. The curve provides several kinetic performance indicators, including the onset potential (E onset), overpotential (η j), and diffusion-limiting current density (j L), which are commonly used to compare the overall ORR activities of different electrocatalysts [35]. Fig. 3(c) illustrates a representative ORR polarization curve obtained using an RRDE [39]. The H2O2 molar selectivity and the average number of electrons transferred (n) [41] are determined by comparing oxygen reduction current at the disk (i d) and H2O2 oxidation current at the platinum ring (i r) [30]. (12) H 2 O 2 ( % ) = n H 2 O 2 n H 2 O 2 + n H 2 O = 200 × i r / N i d + i r / N (13) n = 4 × i d i d + i r / N where N denotes the collection efficiency of RRDE, representing the fraction of species generated at the disk that reaches the ring. An n value approaching 2 suggests high selectivity for the two-electron pathway leading to H2O2 production, whereas an n value near 4 indicates a preference for the four-electron pathway. To assess catalyst performance more realistically, the actual production of H2O2 should also be tested and quantified using an electrolyzer (Fig. 3d). Such device-based evaluations better reflect catalytic behavior under practical operating conditions, including long-term stability and large-scale H2O2 generation. H2O2 concentration can be quantified using cerium sulfate titration or by colorimetric analysis with potassium titanium oxalate [42,43]. The Faradaic efficiency (FE) of H2O2 production in the electrolyzer can be calculated as follows. (14) F E = 2 × c H 2 O 2 × V × F Q where c H 2 O 2 is the concentration of produced H2O2; V, F, and Q denote the electrolyte volume, Faraday constant, and total charge transferred, respectively. 3 Biomass-derived carbon materials Conventionally, most functional carbon-based materials are typically derived from coal or petrochemical products via synthesis methods with high energy demands and harsh reaction conditions, rendering the production costly and unsustainable [44]. For example, graphene and carbon nanofibers/tubes are commonly fabricated via chemical vapor deposition (CVD) or arc discharge techniques using gaseous petrochemical products (e.g., ethylene and methane) as carbon sources at temperatures above 800 °C [45,46]. Activated carbon is typically obtained from non-renewable feedstocks such as coal through activation treatments [47]. Unlike fossil fuel-derived carbon precursors, biomass, especially agricultural and forestry residues, offers advantages such as low cost, abundant supply, sustainable availability, and widespread accessibility [48]. It provides a promising alternative carbon source for synthesizing various carbon materials, as well as valuable products such as sugars, lipids, and bio-oils [49]. Beyond environmental benefits and cost-effectiveness, biomass utilization enables the preparation of functional carbon-based materials with several additional advantages. Since biomass inherently contains elements such as C, O, S, N, and P, heteroatom self-doping can occur during synthesis, eliminating the need for external dopants, concentrated acids, or strong oxidants and thus ensuring a more environmentally friendly and sustainable process [50–54]. Moreover, a wide range of morphologies (1D fibers, 2D sheets, and 3D foams) [55] can be engineered through precursor selection, while biomass derivatives possess tunable structures, allowing for the tailoring of specific surface area, porosity, and crystallinity. Through techniques such as hydrothermal carbonization, pyrolysis, laser-induced carbonization, flash Joule heating, and microwave treatment, these physical and chemical properties can be tailored to enhance electrochemical performance. In recent years, biomass-derived carbon materials have been applied extensively in electrochemical energy storage and conversion [44,56–59], including batteries, supercapacitors, and fuel cells, as well as functional electrodes for reactions such as ORR and oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [40,60,61]. 3.1 Biomass precursors According to the International Energy Agency (IEA), biomass encompasses all organisms produced via photosynthesis, including plants, animals, and microorganisms. In general, biomass precursors are classified into plant-based and animal-based sources. 3.1.1 Plant biomass Plant biomass includes macromolecular lignocellulose, small-molecule biomass, and related derivatives [49,62]. Generally, lignocellulose consists of 40 %–50 % cellulose, 20 %–25 % hemicellulose, and 15 %–35 % lignin [62]. Cellulose, composed of β-1,4-linked anhydro-D-glucose units, constitutes the predominant carbohydrate in plant cell walls, where it serves as the fundamental structural framework in the form of fibrous bundles. These polymeric chains are further organized into microfibrils through the interplay of van der Waals interactions and extensive hydrogen bonding, conferring stability and mechanical integrity to the cell wall matrix [63]. Pyrolysis represents an efficient strategy for synthesizing carbon materials derived from cellulose. Dong et al. obtained CuO and Cu@C hollow microfibers by fast pyrolysis (at 600 °C for 1 h) of cuprammonium cellulose filaments in air or argon atmosphere (Fig. 4 a) [64]. Zhang et al. investigated the impact of pyrolysis temperatures on the functional groups and structural characteristics of biochar. They observed that low-temperature pyrolysis produced predominantly aliphatic biochar, while structural rearrangement of the feedstock was initiated around 430–440 °C, resulting in the formation of abundant C=O groups. Further increase in pyrolysis temperature facilitated the development of graphitic structures, improved thermal stability, and enhanced biochar porosity [65]. Unlike traditional pyrolysis that typically necessitates high temperatures, Wang et al. employed an oxygen-isolating strategy to directly extract cellulose nanofibers (CNFs, Fig. 4b). Within the confined space of the CNFs, highly graphitized carbon was formed at only 90 °C and ambient pressure. This process enabled the bottom-up synthesis of large-scale twisted graphene films from CNFene suspensions [66]. Unlike cellulose, hemicelluloses are a complex assembly of polysaccharides characterized by lower degrees of polymerization and structural diversity, ranging from linear to highly branched configurations. They primarily consist of pentose and hexose sugars, along with hexuronic acids and acetyl groups that serve as functional building blocks [71]. Hemicellulose polysaccharides are generally susceptible to hydrolysis in dilute acidic or basic conditions and are readily soluble in alkaline solutions, making them traditionally considered extractable polysaccharides [72]. Lin et al. used pomelo peel to prepare the hemicellulose-derived porous activated carbon (HPAC, Fig. 4c), using ZnCl2 as the nitrogen-fixing agent and structural template. The HPAC exhibited a high specific surface area of 1361 m2 g−1 [67]. Wang et al. extracted hemicellulose from hemp stem to prepare carbon spheres, which exhibited an exceptionally high specific surface area of 3062 m2 g−1 [73]. Lignin, functioning as a “glue” that binds the lignocellulose matrix and strengthens plant cell walls, is a three-dimensional, highly cross-linked aromatic polymer. It is primarily composed of guaiacyl (G), syringyl (S), and p-hydroxyphenyl (H) phenylpropane units interconnected by C–O and C–C covalent bonds [62]. Lignin can be obtained from black liquor, a dark brown by-product of the pulping industry, which is usually burned for energy cogeneration currently [74]. Hydrothermal carbonization (HTC) and pyrolysis are effective methods for transforming lignin into valuable carbon materials. Ma et al. applied HTC to process alkali lignin from black liquor into lignin hydrochar and carbon quantum dots [74]. Compared with cellulose and hemicelluloses, lignin possesses the greatest thermal stability owing to its aromatic ring structure, resulting in a relatively low degree of graphitization. Guan et al. employed flash Joule heating (FJH) to promote the graphitization of lignin, and found that higher applied voltage resulted in denser and more ordered graphite-carbon structures [75]. Due to the abundance of aromatic structures and oxygen-containing groups, the coordination capacity of lignin with metal ions can be enhanced with moderate pretreatment or modification to form lignin-metal framework complex [76,68]. Lin et al. synthesize a nitrogen-doped, carbon-encapsulated CoRu nanocatalyst complexes (CoRu@OALC, Fig. 4d) via oxidative ammonolysis of lignin, achieving low overpotentials of 90 mV in HER and 200 mV in OER at 10 mA cm−2. The oxidative ammonolysis process facilitates the conversion of metal ions to their metallic state, leading to the formation of a wrapped alloy structure at 600–700 °C [68]. Cho et al. fabricated mixed metal-biochar composites similarly using red mud and lignin. During pyrolysis at 700 °C, Fe oxides in the red mud were reduced to metallic Fe by lignin-derived decomposition products [77]. Apart from the macromolecular biomass, small molecules, including glucose produced via hydrolysis of cellulose, and fructose from glucose isomerization, can also be used to prepare functional biochar directly [78]. For example, Wen et al. synthesized hydrothermal carbon enriched with hydroxyl and carbonyl groups from glucose. They found that the smaller, spherical particles exhibited a higher nitrobenzene reduction degree [79]. 3.1.2 Animal biomass Animal biomass refers to the waste or residues of animals, such as feathers, shells, and horns, which are characterized by their complex composition of minerals, proteins, and polysaccharides [80]. Compared to plant biomass, animal biomass exhibits a higher degree of compositional complexity. Here, only several readily available animal biomass precursors that are widely utilized for the synthesis of biomass-derived carbon materials are reviewed. Protein, with amino acids as the basic units, is the basic organic matter of cells. Due to their high nitrogen content, proteins are attractive biomass precursors for the direct synthesis of nitrogen-doped carbon materials, which exhibit improved electrochemical performance [81,82]. In addition, the biodegradable nature makes them environmentally friendly alternatives to traditional electrode materials [83]. Numerous protein-rich biomass sources have been utilized to produce carbon materials, including eggs [84,69], cocoon silk fibers [85], milk [86], soybean [87,88], and keratin [89,90]. Wu et al. used a high-throughput spray-drying method to fabricate uniform mesoporous carbon microspheres (egg-CMS) co-doped with N, P, and Fe, directly derived from eggs without any external doping agents (Fig. 4e). The egg-CMS exhibited a high specific surface area of 970 m2 g−1 and a high pore volume of 0.5 cm3 g−1 [69]. Amiinu et al. utilized horn keratin, which is naturally rich in N/S-containing amino acids (cysteine), as the precursor to prepare 3D porous N, S co-doped graphene through simple pyrolysis. The material showed the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of ∼319.93 m2 g−1 and a predominantly mesoporous structure [90]. Chitin is a kind of linear polysaccharide polymer consisting of 1000 to 3000 acetyl glucosamine units linked through β-1,4 glycoside bonds. It is the most abundant natural nitrogen-containing compound and the second most abundant biopolymer on earth after cellulose [91,92]. Crustacean shells typically consist of 20 %–40 % protein, 20 %–50 % calcium carbonate, and 15 %–40 % chitin. Faced with millions of tonnes of seafood waste, repurposing discarded shells into valuable nitrogen-containing compounds could offer significant economic and environmental benefits [91]. By pyrolyzing the chitin microspheres, Duan et al. fabricated elastic N-doped carbon microspheres, whose morphology recovered completely over five cyclic compressions under 75 % strain [93]. Shang et al. synthesized N-doped, hierarchically porous carbon electrodes in situ by employing chitin nanofibers as biotemplates for zeolitic imidazolate frameworks, effectively mitigating structural fragmentation. The assembled symmetric supercapacitor showed an improved specific capacitance of 128.5 F g−1 at 0.2 A g−1 [94]. Wu et al. fabricated loofah sponge-like N-doped carbon mesoporous nanosheets from chitin and g-C3N4 as a bifunctional catalyst for OER and ORR. Incorporating g-C3N4 into the chitin-derived carbon significantly increased the N content from 5.7 to 13.2 at% [95]. Chitosan is a deacetylated derivative of chitin and the only basic natural polysaccharide. Chitosan, chitin, and cellulose have similar chemical structures, just with an amino group, an acetyl group, and a hydroxyl group at the C2 position, respectively. Single-layer N-doped graphene films were first prepared by Primo et al. from the pyrolysis of chitosan, showing over 99 % transmittance [96]. Sun et al. fabricated isolated boron and nitrogen co-doped porous graphitic carbon (BNGC) using a two-step process that involved hydrothermal coordination followed by ZnCl2 activation, with chitosan and boric acid (H3BO3) as the precursor and dopant, respectively (Fig. 4f). The BNGC exhibited a capacitance of 313 F g−1 at 1 A g−1 and FE of over 99.5 % after 5000 cycles [70]. 3.2 Preparation of biomass-derived carbon materials Various processes have been developed to prepare carbon materials from amorphous biomass precursors, including decomposition, polymerization, aromatization, carbonization, and graphitization [97]. Because of cross-linked structures and randomly oriented crystalline regions, graphitizing biomass precursors generally requires high temperature. Additional thermal treatments or additives are often employed to facilitate the graphitization process [53,54]. HTC [98–100] and pyrolysis [51,54,101] are two widely used methods in a wide range of temperatures for carbonizing and graphitizing biomass. Additionally, laser treatment [102–104], FJH [105,106], microwave-assisted pyrolysis [107], and plasma processing [108,109] have also been adopted to promote graphitization by generating short bursts of high temperature. 3.2.1 Hydrothermal carbonization Due to the naturally high moisture content of biomass, HTC, which typically operates at 180–260 °C, offers higher energy efficiency for preparing high-carbon products (e.g., hydrochar, graphene quantum dots) than pyrolysis, which requires a drying pretreatment step [97,100]. If the temperature is higher than 260 °C, the process is defined as hydrothermal liquefaction (HTL), hydrothermal gasification (HTG), or supercritical water gasification (SCWG), where liquid or gaseous hydrocarbon products are formed, respectively (Fig. 5 a) [110]. The HTC is an intricate process involving many reactions like hydrolysis, dehydration, decarboxylation, polycondensation, and aromatization of biomass precursors [111]. Temperature, residence time, pressure, pH value, and biomass-to-water ratio, especially the first two, are the main adjustable parameters significantly influencing the yield, elemental distribution, and physical and chemical properties of the obtained carbon materials [98,112]. Lorente et al. used brewers’ spent grain as the precursor to produce hydrochar by microwave-assisted hydrothermal carbonization [113]. The results indicated that higher reaction temperatures or longer durations reduced hydrochar production while increasing gas, bio-oil, and aqueous phase yields. This shift also resulted in lower oxygen content and a higher carbon content. Sevilla et al. observed that varying the reaction temperature and time influenced the size of glucose-derived carbon spheres (Fig. 5b) [114]. The structural composition of carbohydrate-based HTC is primarily described by two distinct models: a functionalized polyaromatic network resembling lignin or an alternative framework composed predominantly of furanic structures instead of aromatic rings [115]. Fig. 5(c) presents a Van Krevelen plot (atomic H/C vs. O/C), enabling visualization of how HTC duration and temperature influence both the carbonization process and reaction pathways, while simultaneously providing insight into the resulting fuel properties [99]. As illustrated by straight lines in different colors, the three competing reactions (dehydration, decarboxylation, and demethylation) demonstrate varying degrees of contribution, with dehydration emerging as the primary pathway [99]. Dehydration predominantly removes hydroxyl groups (–OH), enhancing carbonization efficiency while substantially decreasing the O/C atomic ratio. At temperatures exceeding 150 °C, rapid decarboxylation occurs, with decomposition of carboxyl groups (–COOH) to primarily generate CO2 and CO [116]. Ma et al. applied HTC to convert alkali lignin in black liquor into lignin hydrochar (LHC), which could well enhance the biomethane yield (Fig. 5d) [74]. 3.2.2 Pyrolysis Pyrolysis is a thermal decomposition process in an oxygen-free environment that converts organic materials into charcoal, liquid, and gaseous products [117,118]. Pyrolysis above 300 °C can be categorized into three types based on temperature ranges: slow (300–700 °C), fast (500–1000 °C), and flash (900–1200 °C) pyrolysis [98]. Reaction conditions significantly influence product distribution. For example, elevated heating rates and temperatures in fast/flash pyrolysis enhance liquid yields while reducing solid and gas fractions [98], and thus slow pyrolysis results in high yields of porous carbon materials, whereas fast pyrolysis obtains high yields of bio-oil [111]. Generally, pyrolysis of biomass is an integration process of char formation, depolymerization, and fragmentation, which are affected by several parameters such as heating rate, temperature, residence time, biomass composition, and moisture content. The pyrolysis experiments revealed distinct heating rate effects on biochar properties. Rapid heating rate processing produced chars with 49 % greater surface area than conventional heating, along with higher O/H contents and increased structural disorder. Conversely, higher heating rates negatively impacted structural ordering, reducing crystallite dimensions, graphitic alignment, and aromatic condensation compared to slow pyrolysis [119,120]. Yuan et al. also found that slow pyrolysis of walnut shells generated slightly higher biochar yields, free radicals, and quinone contents, but the content of hydroxyl groups was lower [121]. Pyrolysis temperature is another significant parameter affecting the element composition and structure of biochar. For pyrolysis of pine wood (high lignin) and tall fescue grass (low lignin), Keiluweit et al. categorized the generated chars into four structural types: transition chars preserving precursor crystallinity, amorphous chars containing thermally altered molecular mixtures, composite chars with weakly ordered graphene stacking, and turbostratic chars dominated by irregular graphitic arrangements (Fig. 6 a) [122]. Through pyrolysis of amaranthus waste under N2 atmosphere (600–900 °C), Gao's team synthesized N-doped carbon materials. The study observed a positive correlation between pyrolysis temperature and both surface area (663–1008 m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.50–0.80 cm3 g−1), while nitrogen content showed an inverse relationship (4.05 to 1.42 at%). The 800 °C-derived carbon exhibited optimal ORR performance among all tested samples [51]. Selecting an appropriate residence time is also important. Most studies have shown that two hours of pyrolysis is beneficial to the retention of pore structure [123,124]. Although self-doping can be realized during the pyrolysis of biomass, sometimes researchers introduce additives as dopants or templates to increase the amounts of heteroatoms or introduce more structural defects and disorders. Wang et al. prepared O, N co-doped carbon via heating the mixture of lignin and zinc powders at 1100 °C, followed by ammonia treatment at 800 °C (Fig. 6b) [53]. The peak intensity ratio (I D/I G) of on-CZL was higher than that of o-CZL (only O doping) and o-CL (without zinc powder as template) in Raman spectroscopy (Fig. 6c), indicating more structural defects in on-CZL. The large interlayer spacing of on-CZL may be related to the penetration of char by zinc vapor and ammonia treatment, where ammonia can react with the oxygen impurity in the carbon matrix to destroy the π-π attraction between sp 2 carbon layers to increase the interlayer spacing [53]. To enhance the porosity and pore volume of carbon materials, activation is frequently employed either by physical or chemical processes. In physical activation, carbon-based precursors are treated with oxidizing agents such as O2, air, CO2, or steam at high temperatures. In this process, these gases chemically interact with the carbon framework, generating pores through redox reactions that selectively remove carbon atoms [128]. Zgrzebnicki et al. synthesized N-doped furfuryl alcohol-derived activated carbon by polymerization, carbonization, and activation with carbon dioxide at 1273 K. Burn-offs of 1 %, 20 %, 73 %, and 88 % (AC-1/20/73/88) were confirmed for materials activated for 15, 60, 120, and 240 min, respectively, showing different adsorption and desorption isotherms of nitrogen (Fig. 6d) [125]. The chemical activation process utilizes activating agents (e.g., KOH, K2CO3, ZnCl2, and H3PO4) to chemically etch carbon matrices and create porous networks [70,128,129]. Illingworth et al. studied the mechanism of pyrolysis and alkali chemical activation of fibrous biomass, and found that KOH activation preferentially forms micropores at lower temperatures before enlarging them at higher temperatures, while K2CO3 produced carbons with more heterogeneous porosity and lower micropore volume at comparable activation extents [130]. 3.2.3 Other methods Laser-induced carbonization process is conducted through photothermal conversion, with concentrated laser energy generating extreme localized heating on polymer surfaces. This rapid thermal excitation disrupts molecular bonds through lattice vibration, drives off gaseous byproducts, and promotes structural rearrangement into carbonized networks [102,131]. Polymer substrates, phenolic resins, and lignocellulose materials are mainstream carbon precursors converted to laser-induced graphene [132]. Ye et al. converted wood into hierarchical porous graphene exhibiting excellent electrical conductivity (10 Ω per square) using CO2 laser scribing (Fig. 6e and f), where inert atmosphere, moderate laser intensity, and composite structure of wood are three critical factors leading to a more stable graphene structure [103]. Yuan et al. developed a heteroatom-rich graphene material through laser-assisted processing of a modified wood substrate. The composite precursor consisted of carboxymethyl chitosan (serving dual functions as viscosity modifier and O/N source) and sodium lignosulfonate (providing O/S doping elements). This innovative approach achieved significant heteroatom incorporation in the graphene matrix, with elemental doping levels of 13.27 wt% oxygen, 2.06 wt% nitrogen, and 1.68 wt% sulfur [104]. Flash Joule heating (FJH) enables rapid electrothermal transformation of the amorphous carbon into turbostratic flash graphene (FG) between two electrodes (Fig. 6g and h) [126]. This technique employs high-voltage electrical pulses to instantaneously (<100 ms) heat carbon precursors to extreme temperatures exceeding 3000 K [105]. Abundant renewable or waste-sourced carbons such as coffee grounds, lignin, pine bark, sawdust, wheat straw, corn straw, and rice straw, olive oil soot, cabbage, coconut, pistachio shells, potato skins, charcoal, biochar, humic acid, sucrose, starch, keratin (human hair), rubber tires, and mixed plastic have been proved for production of FG by FJH [105,106]. Microwave-assisted pyrolysis (MAP) has a different temperature distribution and heat transfer from conventional heating (Fig. 6i) [107]. Using MAP at 500 °C, Shi et al. prepared multi-walled carbon nanotubes (MWCNTs) with controlled dimensions (50 nm diameter, ∼5 nm wall thickness), while no MWCNTs were detected under conventional heating conditions (Fig. 6j–m) [127]. Plasma offers a chemically reactive environment containing various active species (radicals, ions, and excited molecules) derived from simple hydrocarbon precursors, allowing for lower temperatures and faster growth to prepare carbon materials [108]. Shah et al. used mango peel as a non-cost carbon precursor for graphene production. They found a correlation between processing time and layer thickness, with shorter exposures (15/30 min) producing multi-layered graphene and prolonged treatment (60 min) resulting in single-layer sheets due to plasma-induced layer-by-layer etching [109]. 4 Self-doped biomass-derived carbon catalysts for 2e− ORR Carbon materials generally exist in three allotropes: graphite (sp 2 bonding), diamond (sp 3 bonding), and amorphous carbon (sp 2 and sp 3 bonding) [33]. However, the inherent chemical inertness of π electrons in conventional carbon frameworks hinders effective adsorption and activation of O2 or ORR intermediates, leading to lower catalytic activity and selectivity in 2e− ORR compared to metal-based catalysts (Fig. 7 a) [133]. This limitation restricts their direct application in oxygen reduction catalysis [134,135]. To overcome these challenges, numerous efforts have been devoted to enhancing the catalytic performance of carbon materials through strategies such as heteroatom doping, defect engineering, and modulation of electronic structure [136]. Unlike synthetic carbons, biomass precursors naturally contain a variety of heteroatoms (e.g., oxygen, nitrogen, sulfur, and phosphorus), which can be spontaneously doped into the carbon matrix during carbonization. This self-doping process not only introduces abundant active sites and optimizes charge distribution but also eliminates the need for external dopants, concentrated acids, or harsh oxidants, resulting in a more environmentally benign and sustainable synthesis route. These unique features make biomass-derived carbon catalysts particularly attractive for selective H2O2 production via the 2e− ORR pathway. 4.1 Heteroatom doping Heteroatom doping involves the substitution of carbon atoms within the carbon framework by nonmetallic heteroatoms such as N, B, O, F, P, S, Cl, Br, and Se [33]. As illustrated in Fig. 7(b), a segment of the periodic table highlights more than ten nonmetallic elements (outlined in red) that have been successfully incorporated into sp 2-hybridized carbon structures [136]. Introducing heteroatoms with diverse electronegativities, atomic radii, and bonding configurations can effectively tailor the local spin density and charge distribution within the carbon matrix. This enables precise modulation of surface polarity, optimizes the interaction between active sites and ORR intermediates, and enhances the balance between hydrophilicity and hydrophobicity [136]. Biomass precursors, naturally rich in elements such as O, N, S, and P, offer a unique advantage in enabling in-situ heteroatom self-doping during carbonization. This spontaneous incorporation of heteroatoms not only simplifies the synthesis process but also provides a greener and more sustainable pathway to introduce catalytically active sites. Moreover, the intrinsic heterogeneity and hierarchical architecture of biomass feedstocks not only facilitate the formation of multi-scale porous structures during carbonization, but also provide a diversity of doping sites and configurations, thereby improving mass transport and boosting the electrocatalytic activity of the resulting carbon materials in 2e− ORR. 4.1.1 Oxygen self-doping Oxygen is the most commonly introduced dopant in biomass-derived carbon materials, largely owing to the ubiquitous presence of oxygen-containing compounds in natural biomass. During carbonization, this inherent oxygen content enables in-situ self-doping of oxygen functional groups (OFGs) without the need for external oxidants or post-treatment. The incorporation of OFGs, such as ether (C–O–C), carboxyl (–COOH), carbonyl (–C=O), and hydroxyl (–OH), modulates the surface charge distribution of adjacent carbon atoms and alters the adsorption behavior of oxygen reduction intermediates. This regulation plays a crucial role in tuning the activity and 2e− selectivity of carbon-based electrocatalysts. Increasing evidence suggests that not only the type but also the location and electronic environment of OFGs significantly influence the catalytic pathways [28,42,141]. Both experimental characterization and density functional theory (DFT) calculations confirm that C–O–C ether bridges and carbonyl (–C=O) groups serve as primary active centers for the two-electron oxygen reduction pathway, whereas hydroxyl (–OH) functionalities exhibit negligible catalytic activity [28,42,141]. Lu et al. prepared oxidized CNTs (O-CNTs) through controlled nitric acid oxidation, systematically varying the oxygen content (up to 9 at%) by modulating reaction duration (0–48 h). The introduced oxygen species density was linearly correlated with both electrocatalytic activity and two-electron pathway selectivity [42]. Kim et al. prepared a few-layered graphene oxide electrode with mild reduction (F-mrGO) with much less catalyst aggregation and high concentrations of epoxy or ring ether groups located either on their basal planes or at plane edges, exhibiting high activity (<10 mV overpotential), selectivity (∼100 %), and stability (over 15 h at 0.45 V) in alkaline conditions [141]. In addition, Han et al. verified that the quinone-enriched samples exhibited the high selectivity reaching 97.8 %, which was superior to previously reported etheric ring and carboxylic acid groups (Fig. 7c and d), and the theoretical activity volcano plot for oxygen reduction to hydrogen peroxide (ORHP) showed that Q-basal 2–2 displayed the highest activity (Fig. 7e) [28]. Oxygen self-doped biochar can be prepared by simple pyrolysis of biomass with high oxygen content. Due to the high O:C atomic ratio of D-glucose (1:1), Guo et al. developed oxygen-rich carbon quantum dots (30.4 at% O) via hydrothermal dehydration and carbonization of D-glucose. The O-rich catalyst exhibited a production rate of 10.06 mg cm−2 h−1 with 97.7 % FE, while maintaining stable operation for over 10 h in an H-type cell [142]. The carbon atoms in the C–O bonds of ether groups were the most active sites for the 2e− ORR. Wang et al. employed waste pitaya peel as the carbon precursor to prepare an oxygen self-doped hierarchically porous electrocatalyst by pyrolysis and KOH activation (Fig. 7f), which was a simple but effective way to convert food waste into biochar as functional carbon materials. The pitaya peel-derived catalyst exhibited a high H2O2 yield of 41.6 mg h−1 cm−2 but low current efficiency of 65.5 % [137]. Distillers’ grains (DGs), a solid byproduct of the brewing industry, contain abundant crude protein, fiber, and fat components [138]. Hu et al. used DGs to prepare O-doped porous biochar by pyrolysis with KHCO3 as the activating agent (Fig. 7g). The element mappings indicated that the O element content was up to 19.41 wt%. The DG-derived catalyst could generate H2O2 (10 mmol L−1 h−1) in an electro-Fenton system, showing a good degradation performance of bisphenol A [138]. Ball milling represents an effective post-pyrolysis treatment for biochar, serving dual purposes of increasing material packing density while simultaneously introducing structural defects and oxygen-containing functional groups. These modifications significantly enhance oxygen adsorption and improve 2e− ORR selectivity. Gao et al. systematically investigated this process using peanut shells as a low-nitrogen biomass, characterizing the morphological, compositional, and structural transformations. Unlike the sheet-like structure of the original biochar, the ball-milled samples exhibited substantially reduced particle sizes resulting from mechanical fracturing (Fig. 7h), as well as higher H2O2 selectivity of 87 % at neutral electrolyte [139]. Wang et al. used bamboo to prepare O-doped electrocatalyst by pyrolysis, ball milling, and acid treatment (Fig. 7i–k), achieving an H2O2 productivity of 1037 mmol gcat −1 h−1 with a relatively low FE of 74.1 % at 30 mA cm−2 [140]. The O-containing functional groups were successfully introduced into the carbon matrix via physical process and chemical oxidation [140]. 4.1.2 Nitrogen self-doping and N, O co-doping Nitrogen is another widely employed dopant owing to its electronic characteristics and its natural abundance in many biomass feedstocks (e.g., leguminous plants, algae). N, O co-doping has emerged as a particularly effective strategy for modulating the electronic structure and catalytic properties of biomass-derived carbon materials. The effectiveness of nitrogen doping arises from several key factors: (1) dipole-dipole interactions between nitrogen and adjacent carbon atoms increase the local positive charge density and electron affinity [134,143]; (2) hydrogenation of nitrogen destabilizes neighboring carbon atoms and induces charge redistribution [144]; (3) nitrogen incorporation modifies the alkalinity and hydrophilicity of the carbon surface, improving wettability and facilitating charge transport [145]. Various nitrogen species have been identified in pyrolyzed carbon-based electrocatalysts, including pyridinic-N, pyrrolic-N, pyridine-N-oxide, quaternary-N, graphitic-N, and transition metal-coordinated nitrogen (Fig. 8 a) [26,146]. Among them, pyridinic-N and graphitic-N are widely recognized as the primary active sites for 2e− ORR, with their catalytic contributions strongly dependent on the electrolyte environment. Specifically, hydrogenated pyridinic-N has been associated with enhanced activity and selectivity in acidic and neutral media, while graphitic-N tends to serve as the main active site under alkaline conditions [147–150]. This medium-dependent behavior was experimentally confirmed by Sun et al., who tracked the evolution of nitrogen species before and after electrolysis in different electrolytes, highlighting the dynamic nature and functional relevance of nitrogen species in determining the reaction pathway and catalytic efficiency [147]. Tian et al. demonstrated a direct linear relationship between pyridine-N content and the ORR activity [151]. Yang et al. used three different precursors (dicyandiamide, melamine, and urea) to prepare graphite carbon nitrides by pyrolysis in air atmosphere, finding that in alkaline media the 2e− ORR electrocatalytic selectivity of the C3N4 catalysts increased with the increase in the graphitic-N (N-(C)3) concentration (Fig. 8b), but with the decrease in the concentration of pyridinic-N (Fig. 8c), which may be related to the higher electronegativity of graphitic-N promoting the activation of O2 on C atoms [150]. Zhang et al. also found that graphitic-N was the catalytically active composition for 2e− ORR [149]. Xie et al. synthesized N-rich doped carbon (NC) by directly pyrolyzing guanine. The NC obtained at 700 °C with hydrogenated pyridine-N and pyrrole-N exhibited a superior selectivity of H2O2 (up to 96 %) and stable production of H2O2 with productivity of 16.8 mol gcat −1 h−1 in 0.5 M NaCl [152]. Nitrogen-rich biomass and its derivatives offer a sustainable and efficient route for the synthesis of N-doped carbon catalysts via in-situ self-doping during carbonization. For instance, Xue et al. synthesized high-surface-area N-doped activated carbon through high-temperature pyrolysis of ramie, a nitrogen-rich natural fiber. The prepared catalyst exhibited certain H2O2 production capabilities in acidic media, achieving concentrations of 18.1, 14.1, and 11.9 μM after 60 min of reaction in electrolytes with initial H2SO4 concentrations of 0.05, 0.01, and 0.005 M, respectively [156]. In addition, because the undesirable growth of aquatic plants would cause ecological problems, many researchers have used them as precursors. Liang et al. employed water hyacinth as a precursor and mixed it with molten salt ZnCl2 to construct porous polymeric carbon scaffolds, significantly enhancing nitrogen accessibility. XPS analysis revealed a higher nitrogen content in water hyacinth-derived carbon (7.71 at%) compared to that of conventional graphite (1.32 at%). Increasing ZnCl2 concentration promoted the formation of pyridinic-N over graphitic-N, attributed to ZnCl2-mediated trimerization processes [60]. The choice of activating or template agents plays a crucial role in tailoring the pore architecture, surface chemistry, and heteroatom distribution of biomass-derived carbon catalysts. Compared to ZnCl2-templated systems, where molten salt activation often promotes micro-/mesoporous structures, the use of calcium carbonate (CaCO3) provides a gas-releasing decomposition route, generating meso- and macro-porous structures. The structural differences significantly influenced the behavior of H2O2 decomposition: mesoporous catalysts enabled rapid H2O2 release, thereby enhancing selectivity, whereas microporous structures tend to retain H2O2 molecules, increasing their exposure to active sites and promoting undesired further reduction or decomposition (Fig. 8d) [153]. Xin et al. employed low-cost alfalfa as a nitrogen-rich precursor to synthesize N, O self-doped porous carbon (NO/PC) using CaCO3 and potassium oxalate as templates. The prepared catalyst exhibited an H2O2 productivity of 60 mg L−1 h−1 and a relatively low FE of 62 % at 30 mA cm−2 [157]. Moreover, Xin et al. extended the application of the alfalfa-derived NO/PC catalyst by integrating it into a heterogeneous visible-light-driven photo-electro-Fenton system (H-VL-PEF). In this system, the NO/PC served as a cathodic electrocatalyst, while a CuFeO2/biochar particle catalyst functioned as the photocatalyst, forming a synergistic platform for efficient tetracycline degradation under visible light irradiation (Fig. 8e) [154]. This demonstrates the potential of biomass-derived N, O co-doped carbons not only for selective 2e− ORR but also in advanced oxidation processes through integrated photo-electrocatalytic pathways. Panomsuwan et al. prepared nitrogen-doped carbons from cattail leaves (CL-NCs) via hydrothermal treatment in ammonia solution followed by pyrolysis. The resulting materials exhibited nitrogen contents ranging from 0.65 to 1.55 at%, dominated by pyridinic-N and graphitic-N species. While most CL-NCs favored a four-electron ORR pathway (n = 3.23–3.52), the sample prepared in water without ammonia treatment demonstrated the highest two-electron selectivity, highlighting the sensitive role of nitrogen configuration [158]. Furthermore, microwave-assisted synthesis offers a rapid and green method to fabricate nitrogen-doped carbon dots (CDs, Fig. 8f and g). Ghilane et al. utilized glutamine and glucose in an ionic liquid as carbon and nitrogen source, yielding CDs with over 90 % two-electron selectivity across a wide potential range (from 0.6 to −0.2 V vs. RHE) [155]. These examples show that the N, O self-doping from biomass precursors could not only enrich surface active sites and tailor N species distributions, but also provide a low-cost, scalable, and environmentally benign platform for fabricating efficient electrocatalysts for 2e− ORR and H2O2 production. 4.1.3 Sulfur self-doping and boron doping Sulfur doping has emerged as a promising strategy to modulate the electronic structure and reaction pathway for selective 2e− ORR. With a slightly higher electronegativity (2.58) than carbon (2.55), sulfur atoms induce a partial negative charge on themselves and a corresponding positive charge on adjacent carbon atoms, thereby enhancing the electrophilic nature of neighboring carbon sites. In addition, the relatively large atomic radius of sulfur leads to local lattice distortions, promoting the formation of structural defects and active adsorption centers. As demonstrated by Du et al., sulfur atoms alter the local charge distribution, suppress the O–O bond cleavage, and preferentially stabilize the *OOH intermediate, thereby enhancing H2O2 selectivity. When incorporated into a mesoporous carbon framework, S-doped catalysts exhibit outstanding electrocatalytic performance with FE above 95 % and excellent durability [159]. Black liquor (BL), as a wastewater produced by sulfate or caustic soda pulping in paper mills, contains approximately 60 % organic components (predominantly lignin, along with minor amounts of hemicellulose, cellulose, and other extractives) and 40 % inorganic constituents (primarily alkali metals and various salts). Despite its vast generation, most BL is currently burned for energy recovery or directly discharged, leading to severe environmental risks and considerable waste of valuable carbonaceous and inorganic resources [160]. BL presents an ideal carbon precursor for electrocatalyst synthesis, owing to its unique chemical composition and hierarchical structural potential. The three-dimensional aromatic network of lignin serves as a robust carbon skeleton, while the presence of heteroatom-rich functional groups (e.g., methoxy, hydroxyl, sulfonate) facilitates in-situ self-doping of oxygen and sulfur during pyrolysis. Furthermore, inherent inorganic constituents such as Na+, K+, Ca2+, Mg2+, Cl−, SO4 2−, and trace transition metals act as self-activating agents, promoting pore formation and hierarchical structure generation. This integrated organic-inorganic nature enables the simultaneous construction of multi-scale porosity and heteroatom-doped active sites, without the need for extensive external templating or chemical treatments. For instance, Zhao et al. utilized BL and H3BO3 as the raw material and dopant, respectively, to prepare O, S, B co-doped carbon, which exhibited an early onset potential (0.804 V vs. RHE) and an H2O2 selectivity of 78 % [160]. In addition to crude black liquor, sodium lignosulfonate, a water-soluble derivative of lignin obtained from the sulfite pulping process, has also emerged as an attractive biomass precursor for synthesizing heteroatom-doped carbon materials. Its high aromatic carbon content, along with abundant oxygen- and sulfur-containing functional groups (e.g., –OH, –SO3 −, –COOH), enables in-situ O and S self-doping during thermal conversion, while its solubility allows for homogeneous mixing with dopants or templates. Li et al. directly used sodium lignosulfonate as a carbon precursor and incorporated it with H3BO3 and silica (SiO2) as a dopant and hard template, respectively, followed by pyrolysis at various temperatures (700, 900, and 1100 °C). The prepared O, B co-doped carbon exhibited a well-defined hierarchical porous architecture, characterized by a high density of meso-pores (Fig. 9 a and b), which facilitated efficient mass transport and reactant accessibility. This structural advantage, coupled with dual heteroatom doping, endowed the catalyst with a high H2O2 productivity of 11812 mmol gcat −1 h−1 and a high FE of 95.7 % [40]. Wu et al. also utilized sodium lignosulfonate with H3BO3, where H3BO3 played dual roles: it chemically bonded with sulfur atoms to form B-S pairs and simultaneously acted as a pore-directing agent, leading to the formation of a highly porous carbon framework (Fig. 9c). The B-S doped porous carbon (BS-C) exhibited an HO2 − selectivity of over 90 % and a mass activity of 756 mmol gcat −1 h−1 during a test of 11 h in a flow cell. DFT calculations further revealed that edge carbon atoms adjacent to B-S pairs served as the most catalytically active sites (Fig. 9d and e), stabilizing the *OOH intermediate and suppressing O–O bond cleavage to favor the 2e− pathway [161]. From the above studies, it is evident that in addition to sulfur doping, boron also plays a critical role as a heteroatom dopant in enhancing the performance of biomass-derived carbon catalysts for 2e− ORR. In B-doped electron-deficient carbon materials, the vacant 2pz orbital of boron conjugates with the π-electron system of carbon, enabling modulation of local charge distribution [134,163]. Xu et al. used coconut shells to synthesize oxidized activated carbon, which was then combined with boron powder and melamine. The resulting precursor was treated in an FJH device, reaching 3000 °C within 1 s and maintained for 30 s to yield B-doped carbon (f-Bs-C). The catalyst exhibited high H2O2 selectivity (91 %–94 %) in RRDE tests and an FE of above 80 % during 11 h of continuous operation in a flow cell [164]. Similarly, Fan et al. developed porous carbon materials by using nitrogen-rich chitosan as the precursor, with Ni microspheres as both catalytic substrate and hard template, and nanoscale h-BN as nucleation seeds to form a graphene/hexagonal boron nitride heterostructure (BN-C, Fig. 9f and g). The BN-C achieved H2O2 selectivity of 86 %–95 %, and DFT calculations results revealed that B atoms at the heterointerface were the main active sites [162]. In addition, cotton stalks, rich in cellulose and hemicellulose, were employed by Li et al. to fabricate activated carbon fiber electrodes, which exhibited excellent adsorption capacity with a methylene blue decolorization efficiency of 93 %, highlighting their strong potential in pollutant removal applications [165]. Similarly, using waste ginkgo leaves as a precursor, Wang et al. synthesized sulfur and nitrogen co-doped carbon (SN-BC) catalytic membranes, which achieved an H2O2 productivity of 49.5 mg L−1 h−1 and a total organic carbon (TOC) removal efficiency of 67.2 % within 120 min under neutral conditions using tetracycline as the target pollutant [166]. These studies collectively highlight the chemical tunability, abundant functional groups, and intrinsic hierarchical structure of agricultural wastes, as well as the synergistic effects of heteroatom doping (e.g., B, O, S), making them highly attractive for selective 2e− ORR and other electrochemical applications. 4.1.4 Phosphorus doping Due to the lower electronegativity than carbon, phosphorus has also been shown to effectively modulate the electronic structure of carbon frameworks, thereby enhancing ORR activity. For example, Gao et al prepared P self-doped biochar with a hierarchical porous architecture by pyrolyzing litchi shells under N2 atmosphere at 900 °C. The material exhibited a phosphorus content of 1.05 at% and a BET surface area of 693 m2 g−1. Despite its structural advantages, the catalyst showed a relatively low FE of 60 % for H2O2 production [167], suggesting that P-doping alone may be insufficient to achieve high selectivity. This indicates the importance of precise control over P doping configurations and pore structure optimization to fully leverage the electronic effects of phosphorus in promoting selective 2e− ORR. To address the challenge of low heteroatom content in doped carbon materials, numerous studies have explored dual-doping strategies to further enhance the catalytic performance [168]. Chen et al. employed EDTA-2 K and NaH2PO2·H2O as heteroatom dopants and porogens to enhance the 2e− ORR selectivity of champ-derived catalyst. Due to the high N, P co-doping amounts (2.9 at% each), a large specific surface area (1388 m2 g−1) and well-developed pore structure, the catalyst showed high electro-Fenton degradation efficiency, achieving over 95 % removal of methyl yellow and mixed dyes within 1 h. Although the H2O2 yield reached 150 mg L−1 during the first hour, a decline was observed thereafter due to potential side reactions or decomposition [169]. Biomass-derived heteroatom-doped carbon catalysts, especially those produced via in-situ self-doping, demonstrate promising electrocatalytic performance for H2O2 generation, benefiting from the natural abundance of elements like N, O, S, and P in biomass feedstocks. Moreover, the low cost, wide availability, and renewable nature of biomass significantly reduce catalyst production costs and align with the principles of green chemistry and sustainability. However, despite these advantages, the selectivity and activity of biochar-based catalysts still require further enhancement. In particular, the complex and heterogeneous structure of biomass poses challenges in clearly identifying and regulating the true active sites, which need continued investigation and rational design strategies in future studies. 4.2 Loading of metal on carbon materials Rich in functional groups such as hydroxyl (–OH), carboxyl (–COOH), amino (–NH2), and phenolic moieties, biomass materials can effectively coordinate with metal ions, serving as natural ligands to form stable M–N x active sites during pyrolysis. These functional groups not only facilitate strong metal binding but also promote homogeneous metal dispersion, suppressing aggregation and enabling the formation of atomically dispersed active sites [170,171]. Additionally, the hierarchical porous structure generated from biomass pyrolysis enhances active site accessibility and mass transport. For instance, nanocellulose has been shown to direct the in-situ growth of metal-organic frameworks (e.g., ZIFs) through cobalt coordination, leading to high-performance Co-N-C catalysts [172]. Such structural and chemical tunability makes biomass an ideal platform for developing cost-effective and sustainable metal-coordinated electrocatalysts for efficient H2O2 production. For metal-loaded carbon-based catalysts, their activity and selectivity are closely related to the electronic and geometric effects. In the following sections, we firstly introduced the two fundamental effects and then discussed the application of metal-coordinated carbon catalysts for 2e− ORR. 4.2.1 Electronic effect The electronic effect refers to the binding energy of the O2 and intermediates to the catalyst surface [1]. The binding energy of *OOH could be described by a key descriptor, ΔG *OOH, and the limiting potential (U) could be plotted as a function of ΔG *OOH in volcano plots, forming a quantitative version of the Sabatier principle. The 2e− ORR thermodynamic overpotential (η O2/H2O2) represents the potential difference from the equilibrium H2O2 formation potential ( U O 2 / H 2 O 2 0 = 0.7 V ) [1]. Based on volcano plots, Koper summarized the binding thermodynamics of the catalytic intermediates in multi-electron transfer reactions to find the best catalyst [173]. Nørskov plotted a theoretical model of the binding energy on different metal surfaces (Pt, Pd, Au, and Ag) to describe the electronic properties and trends of the two-electron and four-electron pathways [174,175]. Stephens identified Pt-Hg as a promising 2e− ORR electrocatalyst [1], and subsequently further established a universal *OOH adsorption energy relationship across diverse metallic and M−N/C materials (Fig. 10 a and b) [12]. Although O2 binding energy serves as a well-established activity descriptor, rare durability predictors have been proposed in electrocatalysis research. Huang et al. put forward a binary experimental descriptor to predict the catalytic activity and stability of Pt-alloy [176]. Recently, Li et al. have revealed a pH-dependent transition in ORR activity volcanos, from a single peak in alkaline media to a double peak in acidic media, which further refined the Sabatier principle [177]. (15) O 2 + ∗ + ( H + + e - ) → ∗ O O H (16) ∗ O O H + ( H + + e - ) → H 2 O 2 + ∗ As shown in Fig. 10(a and b), the catalysts on the right side of the volcano bind *OOH too weakly, which is limited by *OOH formation (Eq. (15)). For example, Au(211) has a ΔG *OOH of 0.41 eV uphill to form *OOH at U O 2 / H 2 O 2 0 , indicating an overpotential of 0.41 V for the reaction. Catalysts on the left side bind *OOH too strongly, such as Pt or Pd, which is limited by the reduction of *OOH to H2O2 (Eq. (16)). The ideal catalyst is at the peak of the volcano (ΔG *OOH ∼4.2±0.2 eV) [1,12]. Moving further right across the peak of the green line, the O–O bond cleavage in *OOH becomes increasingly energetically unfavorable, whether through chemical dissociation or electrochemical reduction pathways, which means the interaction of *OH and *O with the catalysts gets weakened to the right side, and thus the activity of the metal decreases, but the selectivity of 2e− ORR increases. It can be concluded that H2O2 is energetically preferred over nickel, silver and platinum catalysts, whereas H2O is preferred over ruthenium, iron and cobalt catalysts [12], because the former metal centers are not as oxyphilic as the latter, making the *OOH be more prone to protonation to form H2O2, while the latter metal centers prefer to break the *OOH intermediates to *O, leading to formation of H2O [181]. The volcano plots also can be expanded to describe the relationship between the kinds and locations of different heteroatoms with the performance of the catalysts [28,29]. 4.2.2 Geometric effects Catalyst selectivity is governed by not only the electronic properties but also the surface atomic geometry, which modulates reactant orientation and active site accessibility to destabilize *O and strengthen the O–O bond stability in *OOH to improve the selectivity [1]. One strategy is adsorption configuration design [178,179]. As shown in Fig. 10(c), on pristine Pt/C catalysts, O2 adopts a side-on adsorption configuration and undergoes complete reduction to H2O. In contrast, carbon-coated Pt surfaces promote end-on O2 adsorption, yielding both H2O (via dissociation) and H2O2 (through desorption). The carbon overlayer prevents further reduction of formed H2O2 while enhancing catalyst stability by inhibiting Pt leaching in acidic media [178]. Besides, adding a small number of alkali metal cations displays a “shielding effect”, which squeezes away the catalyst/electrolyte interfacial protons to prevent further reduction of generated H2O2 to H2O (Fig. 10d) [179]. Both of the above strategies are good ways to obstruct the adjacent sites by using inert substances to form single active sites. However, the obstructed site ratio is not easy to control, and the catalytic activity could be limited by an excessive obstructed site ratio. Another controllable site isolation strategy is to control the catalyst loading. Typically, reducing the loading of metal could achieve the dispersion of active sites. Yang et al. investigated this effect by adjusting the concentration of platinum on titanium nitride from 5 to 0.35 wt%. The higher loading (5 wt%) resulted in the formation of Pt nanoparticles, while the lower concentration (0.35 wt%) showed no detectable nanoparticles in TEM analysis. The Pt–Pt coordination number of the 0.35 wt% sample was much smaller than that of typical Pt nanoparticles, indicating the presence of isolated Pt atoms (Fig. 10e) [180]. With the decrease in Pt loading, the ORR current decreased, but the selectivity of H2O2 production increased significantly, which could be explained by the strong adsorption of aggregative active sites (Pt nanoparticles) but moderate adsorption of isolated Pt atoms. The O–O bond of oxygen molecules adsorbed on adjacent active sites tends to break to form H2O, while the single Pt atom cannot further break the O–O bond thus producing H2O2. In addition, the mass activity of SAC is usually higher than that of nanoparticles, which increases the utilization rate of noble metal. Advantages of SAC in terms of reaction selectivity and catalyst mass activity have attracted great interest in recent years [182–185]. Moreover, due to the strong adsorption of *OOH, platinum-group metals are recognized as the most active ORR catalysts for the four-electron pathway to form H2O [186,187]. Alloying with other catalytically inactive metals, like Hg and Au, to form alloys such as Pt-Hg [1], Au-Pd [188], and Pd-Hg [12], could reduce the binding energy to increase the selectivity of the two-electron pathway, which makes the methods of active site isolation more diverse. 4.2.3 Loading of transition metals Noble metals and their alloys have a small overpotential and a high H2O2 selectivity for 2e− ORR. However, the scarcity and high cost of noble metals are not conducive to their large-scale application. Recent studies indicate that transition metals, like Fe, Co, Ni, Mn, and Zn, also exhibit electrocatalytic activities for H2O2 production [31,135,181,182,189–192]. For example, Xu et al. fabricated carbon materials by anchoring oxygen-coordinated Fe single atom on bacterial cellulose (FeSAs-BCC), which exhibited a high H2O2 selectivity of 96.5 % in 0.1 M KOH. In a flow cell at 150 mA cm−2, the catalyst achieved a yield rate of 12.51 mol g−1 h−1 and an FE of 89.4 %. DFT calculations revealed that the oxygen coordination effectively modulates the electronic structure of the Fe active centers, optimizing the *OOH intermediate binding strength and thereby enhancing the 2e− ORR pathway for efficient H2O2 production [192]. Co has garnered significant interest because of the tunable *OOH binding strength for H2O2 production [193]. However, the well-known Co-N4 exhibits limited selectivity for H2O2 due to the strong binding energy of *OOH. Researches indicate that oxygen-functionalized Co-N4 sites exhibit weakened *OOH adsorption, leading to enhanced H2O2 selectivity [31,135,181,189,194,195]. Through the cobalt coordination capability of one-dimensional nanocellulose (CNF), which is inherently rich in –OH and –COOH functional groups, Qian et al. proposed a cost-effective strategy to develop high-performance Co-CNF electrocatalysts for selective 2e− ORR. These surface groups enabled the direct and facile growth of nanostructured zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) around the CNF backbone (Fig. 11 a–c) for subsequent carbonization. The Co-CNF electrocatalyst exhibited an H2O2 productivity of 510.58 mg L−1 cm−2 h−1 [172]. Tang et al. prepared a N, O dual-coordinated CoNOC catalyst with C–O–C groups, which exhibited high selectivity (>95 %) for acidic H2O2 electrosynthesis (Fig. 11d and e) [189]. Jung et al. retained the oxygen-containing functional groups by mildly reducing the metal-adsorbed GO at 500 °C in NH3/Ar, preserving a high percentage of oxygen (6.6 at%) and achieving an increase in the H2O2 selectivity from 40 % to 80 % [181]. Guided by first-principles calculations, they found that the surrounding atomic configuration could regulate the catalytic properties of the Co-N4 moiety. When electron-rich species, like *O, are adsorbed near the Co-N4 (Co-N4(O)), ΔG *OOH increases from 3.9 to 4.1 eV, being close to the optimal value for the H2O2 production. ΔG *OOH can be further increased to 4.5 eV when two *O are adsorbed near the Co-N4 (Co-N4(2O)). Similar conclusions have been drawn for *OH. However, when electron-poor species, such as *H, are adsorbed near the Co-N4 (Co-N4(2H)), ΔG *OOH decreases from 3.9 to 3.8 eV and further to 3.1 eV on Co-N4(4H) (Fig. 11f). Similar trends are observed for C in Co-N3C [181]. Metal phthalocyanines serve as model catalysts with well-defined structures, which have also been widely used in ORR [135,197]. Based on cedarwood, an abundant and renewable biomass with a naturally hierarchical porous structure, Liu et al. synthesized a CoPc-modified oxygen-doped cedarwood carbon catalyst (CoPc@OCW, Fig. 11g), where CoPc molecules were anchored onto the carbon surface via π-π interactions. The resulting catalyst exhibited high H2O2 selectivity (>90 %, Fig. 11h and i) and yield of 10.4 mol g−1 h−1, with stable performance over 24 h [196]. Cao et al. also reported a series of oxygen-functionalized transition-metal phthalocyanine catalysts (Co/Cu/FePc-OCNT) with pyrrolic-N4 configuration (Fig. 11j). Among them, CoPc showed the highest activity and selectivity toward the 2e− ORR with a ΔG *OOH of 4.15 eV that was closest to the volcano peak. A continuous 30-h electrosynthesis using CoPc-CNT at 200 mA cm−2 stably produced H2O2 with a concentration of 677–755 mM and a high FE of 91 %–100 % [135]. Transition metal-coordinated biomass-derived carbon catalysts have demonstrated promising 2e− ORR activity and H2O2 selectivity due to their tunable electronic structures and coordinated active sites. A summary table is provided to compare the 2e− ORR performance of recent reported biomass-derived carbon catalysts (Table 1 ) [40,60,137–140,142,157,155,158,159,161,162,184,189–195,197]. The synthesis method plays a critical role in tuning catalytic performance. Advanced techniques like FJH and microwave-assisted synthesis offer rapid, scalable routes, while preserving or even enhancing activity. Meanwhile, traditional pyrolysis remains dominant due to its versatility and simplicity. Besides, the integration of biomass heterogeneity, in-situ doping, and device-level engineering offers a promising pathway toward sustainable, high-performance electrosynthesis of H2O2. 5 Design of electrochemical devices for H2O2 production 5.1 Cathodic electrode architecture engineering For high-efficiency H2O2 synthesis, it is essential to ensure high catalyst selectivity, effective oxygen diffusion, and smooth electron transfer at the cathode reaction surface [198,199]. Carbon materials, including carbon black [200], graphene [141], nanotubus [163], and biochar [157], are recognized as efficient catalysts for H2O2 production. While increased applied potential enhances electron transfer, at high current densities, the ORR becomes limited by oxygen mass transport due to its low solubility in water (∼8 mg L−1 at room temperature and atmospheric pressure), resulting in sluggish kinetics of 2e− ORR and irreversible flooding of electrode by electrolyte [201,202]. In recent years, considerable efforts have been made to address these challenges. Among various approaches, the gas diffusion electrode (GDE) has emerged as a prevalent strategy to enhance oxygen mass transfer in ORR by directly delivering oxygen to the cathode surface, thereby bypassing its dissolution in the electrolyte and improving H2O2 electrosynthesis efficiency [203]. Brillas et al. employed a GDE for electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 using pure O2 at 60 mL min−1, achieving an optimal H2O2 productivity of 59 mg h−1 cm−2 at 242 mA cm−2. However, the GDE exhibited poor structural stability, as it was prone to rapid failure due to electrode flooding when oxygen was not continuously supplied, reflecting its low oxygen utilization efficiency (OUE) [204].
