For the flooding problem, Cui et al. underscored the importance of efficient gas-phase diffusion induced by hydrophobicity, which fostered a local alkaline microenvironment and leveraged electrostatic repulsion to propel H2O2 away from the active site, achieving high electrode selectivity that even surpassed the intrinsic selectivity of the electrocatalyst [205]. Yu et al. used a dual GDE to produce H2O2, achieving an improved OUE of 8.84 %, and a yield of 11.16 mg h−1 cm−2 at 35.7 mA cm−2. Nevertheless, the process suffered from poor energy efficiency, as the aeration energy demand (64.1 kWh kg−1) was over threefold higher than the electricity consumed for H2O2 synthesis (17.9 kWh kg−1) [206]. A similar situation, which might be more serious, was also observed at a pilot plant as reported by Malato’s group [207]. Therefore, improving oxygen mass transfer and OUE in GDEs through advanced electrode design is essential to lower or potentially eliminate aeration energy consumption. Preventing flooding of the electrode is equally important for long-time stability. Several effective strategies have been developed to modify cathodic catalytic interfaces using polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) as a binder, aiming to enhance the 2e− ORR performance of carbon-based catalysts [208–212]. The PTFE mixed with catalysts is usually loaded on carbon felts via impregnation or coating. For example, Yu et al. modified graphite felt with CB and PTFE, achieving a ∼10.7-fold increase in H2O2 production at an optimal CB/PTFE mass ratio of 1:5 [208]. Xu et al. introduced a hydrophobic dimethyl silicone oil coating on the graphite felt cathode to improve its waterproof properties and facilitate oxygen transport [211]. However, directly loading electrocatalysts with mixture of non-conductive binder onto supports may obstruct oxygen diffusion to the catalyst surface, limiting the formation of sufficient three-phase contact points (TPCPs) for the ORR and thereby reducing catalytic efficiency [213,214]. A microporous layer (MPL), typically consisting of CB and a hydrophobic binder (e.g., PTFE), is introduced between the catalyst layer and the support [215]. Zhang et al. developed a natural air diffusion electrode (NADE) with a super-hydrophobic three-phase interface by immersing carbon felt in PTFE and then coating the catalyst layer within the felt structure. This design improved the oxygen diffusion coefficient at the cathode by about 5.7 times and showed good stability compared to the normal GDE system (Fig. 12 a and b). Moreover, two systems without ventilation of air or O2 were also conducted, respectively, which obtained only a very small H2O2 accumulation (Fig. 12c) [199]. Liu et al. prepared a membrane-based GDE (Fig. 12d) by employing a PTFE membrane as both the substrate and connection layer, followed by hot-pressing the electron-conductive layer and catalytic layer onto it. This configuration achieved a notably high operating current density of 1.4 A cm−2 while maintaining a stable FE of 80.6 % [216]. Building an MPL with hierarchical porosity enhances gas diffusion and increases the formation of TPCPs. However, its relatively large thickness (on the order of tens of micrometers) and presence of insulating components can hinder electron transport, leading to greater ohmic losses and reduced performance [213]. To address this issue, Lu et al. introduced an integrated electrode design by constructing micro/nanostructured active materials directly on conductive substrates. This strategy enhanced electrical connectivity between the catalyst and substrate, while the engineered surface morphology allowed for efficient gas bubble adhesion (Fig. 12e) [213,214]. They fabricated cobalt-incorporated nitrogen-doped carbon-nanotube arrays (Fig. 12f) [213] and nickel-incorporated oxidized carbon nanosheets arrays [214] on the Teflon-treated carbon fiber paper (TCFP), a support with microporous layer, high surface area, appropriate electronic conductivity, highly hydrophobic surface, and abundant TPCP. The catalysts showed a long-term stability under high current densities [213]. Cao et al. also used TCFP as the support to prepare three-phase N-doped carbon nanopolyhedra with high hydrophobicity, which facilitated oxygen transport and enabled the durability for 200 h electrocatalytic H2O2 production at 100 mA cm−2 in 1.0 M KOH [217]. 5.2 Design of electrolyzer and in-situ generation device 5.2.1 Key components of electrolyzer Electrochemical reactors for continuous, decentralized H2O2 production primarily consist of flow field plates (FFPs), catalyst layers, gas diffusion layers, membranes, and electrolyte chambers (Fig. 13 a) [218]. FFPs provide gas flow channels to enhance the interaction between gas and catalyst. To improve mass transfer between the gas and electrocatalyst, factors such as plate material, channel geometry, gas flow rate, and interfacial resistance must be carefully considered when selecting or designing FFPs. Currently, three predominant flow field configurations are widely adopted: serpentine, parallel, and interdigitated designs [219,220]. In practical applications, the serpentine flow field has demonstrated excellent performance, with effective product removal, minimal risk of liquid flooding, prolonged residence time, and enhanced coverage of reactive gases [220]. Ion exchange membranes, typically composed of polymers with ion-conducting properties, are essential components in H2O2 electrosynthesis devices. Their performance is mainly assessed by membrane resistance (mS cm−1) and ion exchange capacity (mmol g−1) [221,222]. Proton exchange membrane (PEM) systems offer excellent electrochemical performance but are limited by their reliance on scarce and costly Pt/Ir-based catalysts, hindering large-scale application [223]. In contrast, anion exchange membrane (AEM) systems enable the use of low-cost, non-precious metal catalysts and present a more sustainable and economical alternative. However, their broader deployment remains constrained by the need for scalable, durable, and high-performance AEM materials [224]. In a solid electrolyte system, minimizing voltage loss across the membrane requires specially engineered cation and anion exchange membranes with high ionic conductivity to enable the selective transport of H+ and HO2 − ions, respectively, to form H2O2 [19]. Besides, the environmental factors, such as the pH value of the electrolyte and extra additives in the electrolyte, also affect the catalyst performance [227,228]. As shown in Table 1, carbon-based catalysts generally exhibit outstanding ORR activity and high H2O2 selectivity in alkaline electrolytes, but comparatively poor activity and FE in acidic electrolytes. Alkaline conditions promote the formation of H2O2 by reducing the number of electrons transferred per oxygen molecule as pH rises. In contrast, acidic environments help suppress unwanted electrode flooding [229]. In acidic electrolytes, the low initial potential results in weak surface interactions between carbon-based catalysts and the *OOH intermediate, thereby hindering O–O bond dissociation. Although this weak interaction can suppress the further reduction of H2O2, leading to relatively high selectivity, the overall catalytic activity remains unsatisfactory compared to that in alkaline conditions. Conversely, in alkaline media (especially at pH > 11.8), deprotonated H2O2 becomes more chemically reactive and less stable, presenting a challenge for product stability. Nonetheless, alkaline conditions are generally more favorable for 2e− ORR on carbon-based electrodes. The high concentration of OH− promotes O2 adsorption and facilitates end-on adsorption configurations that selectively yield H2O2 while suppressing its further reduction. Additionally, excessive OH− may partially poison active sites, reducing the density of reactive centers and further limiting unwanted 4e− ORR pathways. Therefore, a trade-off exists between productivity and stability across different pH environments: acidic media offer greater H2O2 stability but lower activity, while alkaline media enhance catalytic performance at the cost of product stability [228,230]. On the other hand, carbon materials and their heteroatom-doped active sites exhibit greater structural and chemical stability in alkaline media [231], whereas acidic conditions often lead to corrosion, protonation, or oxidative degradation of the catalyst or electrolyzer components, affecting the mass activity and operational stability [232]. In addition to pH, halide ions could also influence the electrode surface, and thus regulate the selectivity [233,234]. For example, the introduction of Br− resulted in a more negative onset potential for the ORR and higher selectivity towards the generation of H2O2 rather than H2O [233]. Nevertheless, the underlying mechanisms by which electrolyte composition influences electrocatalytic performance remain to be fully elucidated. 5.2.2 Innovative design of electrolyzer Considering that H2O2 is typically produced alongside various solutes in electrolytes across a wide pH range, additional separation steps are necessary to isolate and concentrate the H2O2 product. Due to the high water solubility, separating H2O2 from strongly acidic or alkaline electrolytes is particularly difficult. Although techniques such as distillation and reverse osmosis can be applied, distillation is extremely energy-intensive, which is comparable to the traditional anthraquinone process, while reverse osmosis relies on costly membranes [14,40]. To overcome these challenges, Murray et al. integrated anthraquinone-mediated H2O2 synthesis with phase-transfer catalysis (Fig. 13b and c) [14]. The process involves three main steps: electrochemical reduction of quinone to hydroquinone in an aqueous electrolyte; transfer of hydroquinone to an immiscible organic phase; its subsequent reaction with an oxygenated pure water stream to produce H2O2 while regenerating the quinone for reuse in the electrochemical cell. This method enables H2O2 generation in an electrolyte-free medium, avoiding separation steps but with a relatively inferior production rate of 2–3 μmol min−1 cm−2 and energetic efficiency of ∼40 % [14]. Xia et al. reported an electrochemical method for directly producing pure peroxide solutions from hydrogen and oxygen [19]. By employing a solid-state electrolyte (Fig. 13d), they effectively prevented contamination from foreign ions [30]. By controlling the water flow rate, H2O2 concentrations of up to 20 % by weight could be achieved [19]. However, the inevitable self-decomposition of H2O2 during its accumulation led to reduced FE, especially in alkaline electrolytes [226]. To solve this problem, many researchers have proposed in-situ use of H2O2, such as disinfection, degradation of organic matter, and generation of value-added chemicals [40,225,226,235–239]. For example, Guan et al. used the in-situ produced H2O2 as an oxidant for oxidative hydrolysis of ethylene to ethylene glycol (Fig. 13e). Based on this strategy, the H2O2 conversion rate and ethylene glycol selectivity reached 86 % and 99.99 %, respectively, with ethylene glycol production rate of 51.48 mmol gcat −1 h−1 and stability of 50 h at a current density of −4 mA cm−2 [225]. In addition, to avoid extra separation processes, solid products would be preferred. The conversion of the alkaline electrolyte containing H2O2 directly into the downstream product, sodium perborate (SPB), has been proposed to reduce the separation cost [239,240]. Lu et al. utilized the generated H2O2 on the electrode surface to continuously synthesize high-purity alkaline-earth metal peroxides (MO2, M = Ca, Sr, and Ba), a category of versatile and clean solid oxidizers. They constructed a carbon self-cleaning electrode with Teflon coating, enabling timely release of the in-situ generated MO2 to solve the block issue. This system achieved high selectivity (∼99 %) and long-term stability (>1000 h) at 50 mA cm−2 for MO2 electrosynthesis (Fig. 13f) [226]. Other reactor systems, like electrochemical jet-cell [201], pressurized reactor [202], and microfluidic devices [241], have also been reported. Increasing the solubility of oxygen in water by using jet-cell or pressurized air or oxygen could theoretically obtain a high concentration of H2O2, but it may cause relatively high aeration energy consumption and waste of gas. The microfluidic devices are relatively difficult to industrialize. Hence, more energy-saving and industry-suitable electrolytic devices still need to be carefully designed for long-term operation. 6 Conclusions and perspectives Biomass-derived carbon-based catalysts hold great promise for the sustainable electrosynthesis of H2O2 via 2e− ORR. The intrinsic heterogeneity and hierarchical architecture of biomass feedstocks facilitate the formation of multi-scale porous structures and diverse doping configurations, which can be achieved by many approaches, including thermal treatment technologies (e.g., hydrothermal carbonization, pyrolysis, and flash joule heating), chemical activation, template method, heteroatom doping, and metal coordination, synergistically enhancing mass transport and catalytic activity. Moreover, biomass precursors, naturally rich in heteroatoms such as O, N, S, and P, offer a unique advantage in enabling in-situ heteroatom self-doping during carbonization. This spontaneous incorporation not only simplifies the synthetic process but also provides a greener pathway to introduce catalytically active sites. In addition, biomass resources are renewable, low-cost, and widely available, making them highly attractive for scalable catalyst production. These features position biomass-derived carbon materials as a promising class of electrocatalysts for selective H2O2 generation. On the other hand, the rational design of electrode architecture and electrolyzer systems, including optimization of electrode configuration (e.g., porous structure, surface wettability) and electrolyzer flow fields for oxygen supply and product diffusion, is equally essential to maximize the efficiency of carbon-based catalyst systems. Although exciting progress on biomass-derived carbon-based materials for electrocatalytic production of H2O2 has been achieved, there are still some issues that need further consideration with regard to the catalytic mechanisms and electrolyzer design for large-scale applications (Fig. 14 ). (1) Elucidating biomass carbonization mechanisms and structure-property relationships. Most current methods for the preparation of biomass-derived carbon materials rely on straightforward “one-pot” thermal treatment (e.g., pyrolysis or hydrothermal carbonization). The transformation mechanisms of individual biomass components (e.g., cellulose, lignin) and their interaction with heteroatoms during carbonization remain poorly understood. A deeper understanding of how hierarchical porosity, heteroatom bonding, and active site exposure arise from different precursors is essential. Under the guidance of the mechanisms, the desired 2e− ORR catalysts with appropriate doping and pore structure could be obtained to achieve high reactivity and selectivity. (2) Utilizing emerging technologies for catalyst discovery and mechanistic insights. The integration of AI-assisted catalyst design and high-throughput screening, as well as operando spectroscopic tools (e.g., ATR-SEIRAS, XAFS), will greatly accelerate the identification of active sites and structure-performance relationships. These tools are expected to uncover dynamic changes in catalysts during the catalyst preparation process and guide the development of next-generation 2e− ORR materials with tailored doping configurations and active sites. (3) Designing efficient electrode systems for industrially relevant current densities. For practical application of H2O2 electrosynthesis, catalysts should operate stably under high current densities (>300 mA cm−2) while retaining high FE. However, mass transport limitations and electrode flooding often reduce energy efficiency and catalytic durability. Strategies such as modifying the hydrophobic/hydrophilic balance of catalyst surfaces and substrates, or using 3D porous conductive frameworks, can improve gas diffusion and electrolyte access, thereby maintaining long-term stability under harsh conditions. (4) Developing industrial-scale electrolyzers. Currently, most lab-scale systems operate below 200 mA cm−2, and FE tends to decline at elevated current densities. It is necessary to further design electrolyzers for industrial scenarios to realize an efficient mass transfer process and long-term stable electrolysis. Electrolyzer structure (e.g., flow channel, plate thickness, and spacing) and operating conditions (e.g., electrolyte type, liquid or gas flow rate) have a great impact on production performance. (5) Assessing cost and environmental impact. Compared with petrochemical-based carbon sources, biomass offers a lower carbon footprint, but a comprehensive techno-economic analysis and life cycle assessment (LCA) are still needed. Using inexpensive waste biomass (e.g., black liquor, lignosulfonates, and fruit shells) as precursors and employing low-energy carbonization processes can reduce production costs. Process optimization, including feedstock pre-selection, additive usage, and temperature control, can further enhance scalability and economic viability. (6) Exploring integrated applications of electrosynthesized H2O2. The in-situ utilization of electrocatalytically generated H2O2 in cascade reactions, such as pollutant degradation, organic synthesis, and energy-chemical conversion systems (e.g., fuel cells, solar-to-chemical devices), offers exciting opportunities for coupling H2O2 generation with downstream applications. Designing cascade reaction modules that directly utilize H2O2 without external separation can enhance efficiency and sustainability. Her researches are focused on electrochemical synthesis of hydrogen peroxide via two-electron reduction of oxygen. Xi Liu is a Ph.D. student in the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, China. Her researches are focused on the electroreduction of CO2 to formic acid, coupling with the electrooxidation of biomass-derived aldehydes (such as 5-hydroxymethylfurfural, furfural, and benzaldehyde). Yichen Zhang is a Ph.D. student in the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China. His research focuses on non-precious metal catalysts for the oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) and theoretical simulations of surface catalysis using DFT. Xuebing Zhao is a tenured Associate Professor and PI in the Department of Chemical Engineering, Tsinghua University, China. He got his PhD degree in the Department of Chemical Engineering at Tsinghua University in 2009. He performed his post-doctoral research at Tsinghua University (2009–2011) and the University of Wisconsin-Madison (2014–2015), respectively. His current researches are focused on the biorefining of lignocellulosic biomass to produce biofuels and chemicals via biological, chemical, and electrochemical approaches. He has published more than 150 academic papers and book chapters in the field of biomass conversion with more than 12000 citations.

coredata.dc:description: H2O2 is one of the most important chemicals in the world. Recently, the electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 by two-electron oxygen reduction reaction (2e− ORR) has attracted great interest. Carbon-based catalysts show great promise for electrocatalytic production of H2O2, due to the ease of regulation of the carbon materials with regard to the pore structure, surface properties, and heteroatom doping. Biomass as the carbon precursor has the advantages of low cost, sustainable supply, and extensive availability. Conversion of biomass to functional carbon-based materials shows the attractive merits, such as low carbon emission in the life cycle and diversity of the obtained carbon materials due to the wide source of biomass feedstocks. In this article, a comprehensive review on the mechanisms and processes of electrochemical synthesis of H2O2 by 2e− ORR over carbon-based catalysts is provided. The potential biomass feedstock used for obtaining the carbon-based catalysts, and the strategies to prepare the catalysts by carbonization and heteroatom doping, as well as optimization of electrodes and design of electrolyzer, are discussed. It is recommended that future work focus on developing efficient methods to prepare the catalysts from low-cost biomass feedstock, understanding the mechanisms of 2e− ORR over the catalysts, optimization of electrode materials loaded with biomass-derived catalysts, as well as development of electrolyzers for larger-scale applications.
